did.unittitle: Video 149: October 8, 1978 Broadcast tape - Highlights of CCTV 3rd TV Production and Performance Workshop with students' assignment

dao.xlink:title: Video 149: October 8, 1978 Broadcast tape - Highlights of CCTV 3rd TV Production and Performance Workshop with students' assignment

daodesc.p: Video 149: October 8, 1978 Broadcast tape - Highlights of CCTV 3rd TV Production and Performance Workshop with students' assignment

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: street interviews, a 35-minute film, and an announcement section. In the street interviews, two hosts interview people about the newspapers they read, their views on international and domestic news, their impressions of last year, and their hopes for the coming year. The second part of the episode is a Curtis Choy film Dupont Guy: The Schiz of Grant Avenue (1976). The film narrates the struggles and experiences of being Chinese American.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes several parts: street interviews, coverage of a photo exhibition and a variety show, a 9-minute documentary, and an announcement section. In the street interviews, two hosts interview people about their views on subways in the city. The photo exhibition shows two Chinese photographers' works that depict life in Chinatown, including sweatshop laborers and street demonstrations for employment equality. The variety show is called China Nite and is organized by a local middle school. The documentary film contains intertitles that read Brute Force Cybernetics presents Second Campaign and Berkeley May 1969.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: a news report on a local demonstration, a 19-minute documentary, and an announcement section. The first part covers housing issues faced by a group of Chinatown residents, who organized demonstrations against the landlord Thomas Sung. Interviews with the disaffected tenants and Thomas Sung (孫啟誠) are included. The second part shows a documentary film Jenny (1977), which is produced by Japanese American Ginny Hashii. The documentary narrates the experiences of being Japanese American in the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: street interviews, a Hong Kong film, and an announcement section. In the street interviews, two hosts interview people about heat provision in their apartments. Interviewees complain about having difficulties getting heat in the winter, and they suggest it is landlords' responsibility to take care of this matter. The second part of the episode is an Allen Fong (方育平) film The Wild Child (野孩子) (1977). The film depicts the ups and downs of a young boy's life who lives with his grandmother in a rural village.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes several parts: news reports on Chinese athletes visiting the United States and Chinese students having dinner gathering, a 26-minute Hong Kong film, coverage of a labor demonstration, and an announcement section. The first part reports the US-China Peoples Friendship Association receiving People's Republic of China athletes who for the first time attend the Winter Olympics. Interviews with athletes and officials from China are included. The second part covers a dinner gathering organized by the National Association of Chinese-Americans. The third part is an Allen Fong (方育平) film Song of Yuen Chau Chai (元洲仔之歌) (1977), which depicts the lives of fishermen in Hong Kong. The fourth section covers a labor demonstration against a Chinese restaurant called House of Chan. Laborers demand recognition of their union by the employer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: a travel program and coverage of a ceremony in New York City. The first part is a program called Travelogue (遊蹤處處), the host introduces a skate rink in Coney Island in New York City, presumably the Abe Stark. Interviews with some skaters are included. The second part covers a ceremony in which President of the City Council Carol Bellamy presents awards to community art groups, including CCTV. The ceremony is held at the Marble Collegiate Church, 1 West 29th Street.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode features activities of Chinese people in New York City celebrating the lunar new year. Activities shown in the episode include singing and dancing shows, martial arts (Kung Fu), and a lion dance performance. The episode also includes interviews with the performers. In the last part, the host of the episode tells traditional stories relevant to the Chinese lunar new year (Year of the Monkey).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: a segment on First Lady Rosalynn Carter's visit to Chinatown, another on a Yale University professor visiting Chinatown with students, and a feature on a Chinese culinary school. In the first part, a banquet is held in a Chinese restaurant to receive Mrs. Carter's visit; Mrs. Carter and others give speeches. The second part includes interviews with the Yale professor - who is Chinese - and the students. The third part features a special program called At Your Service (爲你服務), which introduces culinary and English lessons offered by the China Institute. Interviews with the institute organizer and culinary lesson participants are included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes four parts: street interviews, a lunar new year festival show, a banquet dinner, and an interview with a lawyer. In the first part, the hosts ask people what their views are on the robbery of Chinatown Lincoln Savings Bank. The second part presents a lunar new year performance show organized by the Better Chinatown Project (美化華埠). The third part features a banquet organized by the Chinese American Chamber of Commerce to welcome Winter Olympic athletes from the People's Republic of China. Interviews with athletes are included. The last part is an interview with Benjamin Gim, a representative of the Chinese Lawyers Association.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: a segment on First Lady Rosalynn Carter's visit to Chinatown, street interviews, and a 29-minute documentary. In the first part, a banquet is held at the Silver Palace restaurant to receive Mrs. Carter's visit. Mrs. Carter and other Chinese representatives give speeches. This is the first time the First Lady of the United States visits Chinatown for presidential election fundraising. In the second part, two hosts comment on the disadvantages of smoking and interview people about their views on smoking. The third part is a PBS documentary Emi (1979). The other name of the documentary is Pearls. It is directed by Michael Uno and Frank Nesbitt, about Japanese-American Emiko Tonooka's experience in a California concentration camp during World War Two.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: interviews with children, a segment on a fundraising banquet, and a 35-minute film. In the first part, two hosts interview children and teenagers about their views on watching television. The second part is about a banquet held in Chinatown to support Ted Kennedy running for the presidential election. Present at the banquet include congressman John Murphy, and New York state Kennedy for president campaign manager Richard Donahue. The third part is a Curtis Choy film Dupont Guy: The Schiz of Grant Avenue (1976). The film narrates the struggles and experiences of being Chinese American.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes five parts: a segment on the visit of a Shanghai acrobatic theater, an interview with Chinese playwright Cao Yu (曹禺), coverage of an academic conference, and a special program on the 1980 census. The first part is about the Shanghai acrobatic troupe's US-tour show. The second part covers Chinese playwright Cao Yu's visit to Columbia University. An interview with Cao Yu is also included. The third part is about a conference organized by Asian Women United, a New York-based women's organization. The fourth part is a performance by Chinese singer Zi Wei (紫薇), who is also interviewed. Lastly, the episode includes advertisements to promote the 1980 census, with a special program on the history and operation of census (including interviews with census workers).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: a special program about the 1980 census, a performance, and street interviews. In the first part, the host interviews three census program staff members. They introduce the mission, data collection process, and privacy protection measures of the 1980 census. The second part features a performance by singer Zi Wei (紫薇). The third part includes street interviews with Chinatown residents about their views on the 1980 census.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode is a special program on an acrobatic troupe from Shanghai and their visit to the United States. Included in this episode are stage performances, a reception organized by Chinatown residents to welcome the members, and advertisements of a number of Chinatown stores sponsoring the program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode has four parts: a report on an award presentation banquet in Chinatown, an interview with a Chinese playwright, street interviews, and a special program. In the first part, a banquet is held at the Silver Palace restaurant where the Council of Asian-American Women presents an award to Congresswoman Elizabeth Holtzman. Holtzman is interviewed about her views on immigration and refugee issues. The second part is an interview with Chinese playwright Cao Yu (曹禺). There are scenes from stage performances of Cao Yu's works - the English version of Sunrise (日出) and Peking Man (北京人). In the third part, a host interviews Chinatown residents about their views on the 1980 New York City transit strike. The last section is a special program about the 1980 census. The host interviews three census program staff members, asking them to provide details on the purpose and operation of the census.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode has four parts: a coverage of an award presentation banquet in Chinatown, excerpts of a cultural festival, a feature report about a vocational training school, and interviews with teenagers. In the first part, a banquet is held at the Silver Palace restaurant where the Council of Asian-American Women presents an award to Congresswoman Elizabeth Holtzman. Holtzman is interviewed about her views on immigration and refugee issues. The second part shows excerpts of a music cultural festival held at Shuang Wen School located in Manhattan's Chinatown. The third part is a feature program called At Your Service (爲你服務), which covers a hotel management vocational training school. The school is operated by Jack Han. In the last part of this episode, two hosts interview children and teenagers about their views on watching television.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes four sections: street interviews, excerpts of a cultural performance, a travel program, and interviews with martial art performers. The first part includes street interviews with Chinatown residents. Interviewees express views on the changes of Chinatown, such as the expansion of the Chinese population, and the increasing number of stores and garment manufacture factories. The second part shows excerpts of Chinese Cultural Center's performance at Murry Bergtraum High School. The third part is a program called Travelogue (遊蹤處處). In this episode, Sheepshead Bay in New York City, New York state is introduced. The fourth section introduces a martial art school in Chinatown. The host interviews the school master and Chinese traditional dancing lion performers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode features videos created by participants of CCTV's Production and Performance Workshop held in 1979, the fourth of such sessions. Videos include an advertisement for ballpoint pens, street interviews, a cooking lesson, and a short drama. Interviews with the workshop trainees are also included in this episode.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode has three parts: a travel program, a social service program, and a feature report on a Chinese singer. The first part is a program called Travelogue (遊蹤處處). This episode features the Brooklyn Botanical Garden. The second part is Hello Mother (哈囉阿嬸), in which the hosts interview Ms. Kwan about cosmetic and makeup skills. After the interview, Ms. Kwan has a makeup demonstration. The third part of the video features singing performances by Chinese singer Zi Wei (紫薇).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes five sections: a feature report on a labor strike, street interviews, a cultural program, an interview with Chinese playwright Cao Yu (曹禺), and a 13-minute Hong Kong documentary. The first part features a labor strike outside Silver Palace Restaurant in Chinatown. An unequal allocation of tips is the main issue. In the second part, hosts interview Chinatown residents about their views on the Silver Palace Restaurant labor strike. The third part features a special program called Asian American Experience, in which Asian-American young people are preparing for the American Heritage Week exhibition. The fourth section covers interviews with Chinese playwright Cao Yu. The fifth section of the episode shows documentary Old Man and His Painting (丁公的畫) (1977), in which Chinese painter Ting Yin Yung (丁衍庸)'s life in Hong Kong is documented.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: a coverage of a cultural activity, a social service program, and a feature report of a martial arts contest. The first part covers the second Annual Asian-Pacific American Heritage Festival held at Lincoln Center. The second part is a program called At Your Service (爲你服務), in which the Chinatown Daycare Center is featured. The third part features a martial arts contest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: a feature report on a film festival and coverage of a martial arts contest. The first part features the third annual Asian American International Film Festival which is co-sponsored by New York University film school and Asian CineVision. Also included in this episode are excerpts from films of the film festival: Prince Nezha's Triumph Against Dragon King (哪吒閙海) (1979), Chinese American Second Century, The New Wife, and China: The Land of My Father. The second part of the episode reports a martial arts contest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes four parts: a feature report on a film festival, coverage of a cultural activity in New Jersey, a dance performance, and interviews with CCTV workshop participants. The first section features the opening ceremony of the third annual Asian American International Film Festival which is held at the Tishman Auditorium at New York University. Excerpts of selected film festival films are also included in the episode. The second part is a report on an Asian cultural activity held in New Jersey. The third part covers Chinese classical dance performances at Murry Bergtraum High School. The fourth section includes interviews with participants at CCTV's fifth Production and Performance Workshop.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes four parts: a feature on a theatrical production, a social service program, a travel program, and street interviews. The first part features the Four Seas Players at Pace University in an adaptation of the 18th century drama work Beggar's Opera. The second part is a feature program called At Your Service (爲你服務). In this section, a hotel management vocational training school is introduced. The school is operated by Jack Han. The third part is a program called Travelogue (遊蹤處處), and features the Bronx Zoo. In the fourth section, Chinatown residents are interviewed about their views on roller skating.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: coverage of a cultural activity, a social service program, and street interviews. The first part features cultural performances at Pace University organized by a Hong Kong students association. The second part is a special program called At Your Service (爲你服務) which introduces culinary and English lessons offered by China Institute. Interviews with the institute's organizer and lesson participants are included. In the third segment, two hosts interview people about their views on current television programs and their demands for Chinese television programs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: a special program on a culture activity, a feature on a Hong Kong performance troupe's visit to New York, and coverage of a Chinatown cultural festival. The first part is a special program called Asian American Experience featuring a New York Shakespeare Festival Workshop theatrical production of FOB. The play is written by David Henry Hwang and stars Calvin Jung, John Lone, and Ginny Yang. The second part of the episode is a program called Hello Mother (哈囉阿嬸). Included in this program are excerpts of Cantonese opera performed at the Sun Sing Theater by Hong Kong's Kam Lai Wah opera troupe (錦麗華劇團). Interviews with leading performers Lam Kam Tong (林錦堂) and Ng Kwun-Lai (吳君麗) are also included. The third part covers the 10th Chinatown Summer Cultural Festival.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: a report of an exhibition, street interviews, and a feature on the visit of a Hong Kong performance troupe. The first part covers the 1980 China Decorative Arts Exhibition, held at the United Nations Headquarters in New York City. The second part includes street interviews with people about their views on the increasing cost of living in New York City. The third part features Hong Kong Chor Fung Ming Cantonese Opera troupe (雛鳳鳴劇團 ) and their performances in the United States. Also included in this part are interviews with leading performers: Siu Chung-kwan (蕭仲坤), Lung Kim Sang (龍劍笙), Mui Suet Sze (梅雪詩), Chu Kim Tang (朱劍丹) and Yin Suet Fun (言雪芬), and with the troupe's managers, So Siu-Tong (蘇少棠) and Wong Har-wai (黃夏蕙).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: a segment on social services in Chinatown, a report on a cultural festival, and a feature about a performance troupe. The first part is a program called At Your Service (爲你服務) in which the Chinatown Daycare Center is featured. The second part is called Asian American Experience and covers the 1980 New York Obon Festival, a cultural event that celebrates Japanese traditional culture. The third part features the Hai Jia performance troupe (海嘉綜藝團), originally from the Republic of China. Also included in the episode are the troupe's performing shows during their U.S. tour and interviews with the troupe members.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: a feature on a singing contest, street interviews, and a travel program. The first section is a feature report on a CCTV-sponsored singing competition held at Murry Bergtraum High School. Candidates sing songs in Mandarin and Cantonese. The second part consists of street interviews with people about their views on sanitation issues in Chinatown. The third part is a program called Travelogue (遊蹤處處), in which Sheepshead Bay, a neighborhood in New York City, is featured.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: a feature on a public broadcasting conference, and a 26-minute Hong Kong film. The first part features the first National Conference of Asian Pacific Producers in Public Broadcasting. Excerpts of meetings and discussion sessions are included. The second part is an Allen Fong (方育平) film The Wild Child (野孩子) (1977). The film depicts the life of a young boy living with his grandmother in a rural village.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes four parts: a feature on a Peking opera troupe, a feature on culinary shows, a report on a martial arts performance, and a short documentary. The first part features the U.S. tour of a Peking opera troupe. Excerpts of the troupe's rehearsal are included. In the second part, culinary shows are introduced. The shows take place in Silver Palace Restaurant in Chinatown, by a number of chefs originated from Pan Xi Restaurant (畔溪酒家), Guangzhou, People's Republic of China. The third part of the episode covers a martial arts show. The fourth section is a documentary that includes works by Chinese painter Huang Binhong (黃賓虹).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: a feature on culinary shows, and a 26-minute Hong Kong film. In the first part, culinary shows are introduced. The shows take place in Silver Palace Restaurant in Chinatown, performed by a number of chefs originated from Pan Xi Restaurant, Guangzhou, People's Republic of China. The second part is an Allen Fong (方育平) film Song of Yuen Chau Chai (元洲仔之歌) (1977), which depicts the lives of fishermen in Hong Kong.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode features a martial art performance show at The Yung Wing Public School in Chinatown. The performance is led by Hong Kong martial art master Shih Kien (石堅).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: a feature on Chinese puppet show, and a 35-minute film. The first part features Chinese traditional puppet shows performed by the Quanzhou puppet troupe from Fujian Province, People's Republic of China. The troupe is doing a U.S. tour and had four shows at the American Museum of Natural History in New York City. The second part of the episode is a Curtis Choy film Dupont Guy: The Schiz of Grant Avenue (1976). The film narrates the struggles and experiences of being Chinese American.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode features a 1979 martial arts competition sponsored by CCTV. The participants are of different ethnicities and are practitioners and students from different martial art schools.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes four sections: a brief report on a commerce forum, a feature on the visit of a Hong Kong performance troupe, a travel program, and a 13-minute Hong Kong documentary. The first section is a brief report on the U.S. Secretary of Commerce Philip Klutznick as he attends a forum organized by Chinese American commerce organization to discuss Sino-US trade relations. The second part features Hong Kong Chor Fung Ming Cantonese Opera troupe (雛鳳鳴劇團)'s operatic performing shows in the United States. Also included in this part are interviews with leading performers: Siu Chung-kwan (蕭仲坤), Lung Kim Sang (龍劍笙), Mui Suet Sze (梅雪詩), Chu Kim Tang (朱劍丹) and Yin Suet Fun (言雪芬), and with troupe manager: So Siu-Tong (蘇少棠),Wong Har-wai (黃夏蕙). The third part is program called Travelogue (遊蹤處處) in which the host introduces a skate rink in Brooklyn, New York, presumably the Abe Stark Rink of Coney Island. The fourth part shows documentary Old Man and His Painting (丁公的畫) (1977), in which Chinese painter Ting Yin Yung (丁衍庸)'s life in Hong Kong is documented.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: a report on President Jimmy Carter's Chinatown visit and a 26-minute Hong Kong film. In the first part, Jimmy Carter attends a fundraising banquet held in Silver Palace Restaurant and gives a speech. Interviews with Chinatown residents and banquet participants are also included. The second part is an Allen Fong (方育平) film Song of Yuen Chau Chai (元洲仔之歌) (1977), which depicts the lives of fishermen in Hong Kong.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: a feature on the 1980 presidential election and a report on the New York City marathon. In the first part, various Chinatown activities that support different candidates are featured, including a public assembly to support Reagan for president, President Jimmy Carter's visit to Chinatown, and interviews with Chinese American representatives who actively participate in campaigning. The host also interviews Virginia M. Kee (刘毛淑卿) who is running for Democratic representative in New York State. Instructions on how to cast a vote are also given.The end of this program includes a coverage of the 1980 New York City marathon on October 26, with the starting point in Staten Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode contains two parts: a report on a Chinese acrobatic group's performance, and a 26-minute Hong Kong film. The first part covers a Guangdong acrobatic troupe's US tour. An interview with the troupe leader and highlights of the troupe's acrobatic performance are included. The second part is an Allen Fong (方育平) film The Wild Child (野孩子) (1977). The film depicts the life of a young boy who lives with his grandmother in a rural village.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode contains three parts: a report on a Chinatown community gathering, interviews with Hong Kong celebrities, and a feature on a Hong Kong performance troupe. The first part is a community gathering at the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association. The purpose of the gathering is to collect opinions from Chinatown residents on the newly elected President Ronald Reagan. The second part of the episode includes interviews with two Hong Kong celebrities - singer Chelsia Chan Chau Ha (陳秋霞) and Cantonese opera performer Chan Leung Chung (陳良忠). The third part features Hong Kong Chor Fung Ming Cantonese Opera troupe (雛鳳鳴劇團)'s operatic performances in the United States. Also included in this part are interviews with leading performers: Siu Chung-kwan (蕭仲坤), Lung Kim Sang (龍劍笙), Mui Suet Sze (梅雪詩), Chu Kim Tang (朱劍丹) and Yin Suet Fun (言雪芬), and with troupe manager: So Siu-Tong (蘇少棠),Wong Har-wai (黃夏蕙).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: a report on a martial arts contest, and a 35-minute film. The first part covers a 1980 martial arts competition held at The Yung Wing Public School in Chinatown. Interviews with the first-place winner and the competition's organizer are included. The second part features a Curtis Choy film Dupont Guy: The Schiz of Grant Avenue (1976). The film narrates the struggles and experiences of being Chinese American.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: a report on a Chinese exhibition, a report on the death of John Lennon, and a theatrical production. The first section covers The 1980 Exhibition of People' Republic of China held at the New York Coliseum in New York City. Participants include Ed Koch, Mayor of New York City, Chai Zemin (柴澤民), Chinese Ambassador to the United States of America Ambassador, and Lai Yali (賴亞力), Deputy Permanent Representative of China to the United Nations. Over a thousand people attend. On display are Chinese electronic products and cultural artifacts. The second part covers the death of John Lennon in New York City, a member of the British rock band The Beatles. The third section features a Chinese theatrical production, Old Soldier (老兵), a co-produced by CCTV and the New York Drama Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: a cultural program about Christmas and a television drama produced by CCTV. The first part covers Christmas activities in New York City and includes street interviews with people on their Christmas plans. The second part is a special program called "Asian American Experience" featuring a New York Shakespeare Festival Workshop of FOB. The play is written by David Henry Hwang, starring Calvin Jung, John Lone, and Ginny Yang. The third section is a single-episode television romance drama Autumn Dream (秋夢) produced by CCTV Production and Performance workshop students.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: a special program on John Lennon, and a 26-minute Hong Kong film. The first part pays tribute to John Lennon, a member of British rock band The Beatles who had recently been murdered in front of his apartment building in Manhattan, New York City. The second part is an Allen Fong (方育平) film Song of Yuen Chau Chai (元洲仔之歌) (1977), which depicts the lives of fishermen in Hong Kong.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode shows the 1980 martial arts competition held at The Yung Wing Public School in Chinatown. Interviews with the first-place winner and the competition's organizer are included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode contains three parts: a documentary, a feature on a martial arts performance, and street interviews. The first part is a special program called Asian American Experience in which a documentary about the historical exclusion and mistreatment of Asian Americans in the United States is shown. The second part features a martial arts performance held at the Murry Bergtraum High School. The third part includes street interviews with people about their views on roller skating.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode contains two parts: news coverage, and a social service program. The first part is a program called Times Magazine, which covers international, national, local and Chinatown news.The local news includes the robbery of a Chinatown jewel store, the progress of labor-employer negotiation in Chinatown's Silver Palace Restaurant, and information about a free physical examination program available to Chinatown residents. The second is called At Your Service (爲你服務), which introduces culinary and English lessons offered by China Institute. Interviews with the institute's organizer and lesson participants are included.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Format: 3/4" Umatic, Duration: 60 min., Preservation Note: The tape could not be digitized due to advanced degradation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: news coverage and a social service program. The first part is a news program called Times Magazine which covers international, national, local and Chinatown news. Local news cover an anniversary performance by Chinatown's Four Sea Players is held at Pace University. The second part is Hello Mother (哈囉阿嬸), in which the hosts interview Ms. Kwan about cosmetic and make-up skills. After the interview, Ms. Kwan gives a makeup demonstration.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Original Format: 3/4" Umatic Video, Duration: 60 minutes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: a feature report on a Chinese American politician and a theatrical production. The first part is a feature report on Anna Chan Chennault (陳香梅), spouse of American military aviator major general Claire Lee Chennault. She attends a Chinese American event and talks about her recent visits to Beijing, People's Republic of China, and Taipei, Republic of China (Taiwan). Her visits to Asia is on behalf of the Ronald Reagan administration. The second section features Chinese drama play Old Soldier (老兵), a co-production by CCTV and the New York Drama Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode contains three parts: news coverage, a report on a Chinatown tenant-landlord dispute, and a feature report on ethnic discrimination in the United States. The first part is a CCTV news report which covers international, national, and local news. The second part is a report about a dispute between Chinatown tenants and the landlord called Thomas Sung (孫啟誠). The third part features the history and current status of Chinese Americans and Asian Americans being discriminated against and stereotyped. The feature starts from the launch of a Yves Saint Laurent produced perfume called Opium. Interviews with experts and clips from the documentary The Fist of Righteous Harmony are also included. The host criticizes discrimination and stereotypes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: a report on a protest, news coverage, and a 26-minute film. The first part covers a boycott campaign against the launch of the film Charlie Chan: The Curse of Dragon Queen. Street interviews with people about their opinion on the film and on the boycott are included. The second part is CCTV news report which covers international, national and local news. Local news covered includes a subway workers' strike in New York City, and the New York Police Department's massive search for and arrest of a suspect allegedly involved in murdering three CBS employees. Interviews with two New York policemen are included. The third part is an Allen Fong (方育平) film Song of Yuen Chau Chai (元洲仔之歌) (1977), which depicts the lives of fishermen in Hong Kong.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode features three documentaries. The first is WFAA Production's Welcome to America about Vienamese refugees' life in the United States, directed by Jerry Cadigan and first aired on October 10, 1979. The second is a WNET/Thirteen documentary called New Immigrants, documenting the struggles and anxieties of Korean immigrants in New York City . The third is a 5-minute excerpt from the 1979 Academy Award-winning film From Mao to Mozart: Isaac Stern in China, directed by Allan Miller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes five parts: news reports, a report on a social service club, a report on a film festival, an excerpt of a Hong Kong film, and segments of a puppet show. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The second part covers the inauguration ceremony of the 1981-82 leadership of Lions Club Chinatown. The third part features highlights of the 1971 Asian American Film Festival. The fourth part of the episode showcases an excerpt of Hong Kong film Dangerous Encounter - 1st Kind (第一類型危險) (1980), directed by Tsui Hark (徐克). The last section features Chinese traditional puppet shows performed by the Quanzhou puppet troupe originated from Fujian Province, People's Republic of China.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: news reports and a feature. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week, highlighting the Chinatown Summer Cultural Festival. The second part features a boycott campaign against the launch of film Charlie Chan: The Curse of Dragon Queen Also included are street interviews with people about their opinion on the film and on the boycott.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes four parts: news reports, an interview with a Hong Kong celebrity, a protest, and a segment of a Chinese animation film. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The local news includes a protest by African Americans who demand job opportunities. The protest is held at a construction site on Madison Avenue in New York City. The second part is an interview with Doris Law (羅佩芝) who is a former Miss Hong Kong Pageant recipient. The third part covers a rally at Lincoln Center in New York City, protesting against budget cuts for the arts. Interviews with participating artists are included. The last part of the program shows a segment of a Chinese animated film Prince Nezha's Triumph Against Dragon King (哪吒閙海) (1979).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: news reports, and an interview with a Hong Kong film director. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week including the 1980 United States census results on the population of Chinese Americans. The population numbers were more than 800,000, which exceeded the population of other Asian ethnicities. The second part features an interview with Hong Kong film director Tsui Hark (徐克). Clips from Tsui Hark's films are also included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, a feature on a Chinese performance troupe, and coverage of a cultural festival. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The second part features Shanghai Peking Opera troupe's visit to New York; performances and interviews are included. The third part highlights the Third Asian/Pacific American Heritage Festival, which was held in Lincoln Center on May 2, 1981.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: a news report, and a 26-minute Hong Kong film. The first part includes extensive coverage of international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In the local news section, the host announces the changes and current status of Chinese American population in the country. The announcement is based on the 1980 United States census. The second part is an Allen Fong (方育平) film Song of Yuen Chau Chai (元洲仔之歌) (1977), which depicts the lives of fishermen in Hong Kong.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes news reports that cover international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In local news, the Beautifying Chinatown (美化華埠) project is covered. Street interviews in Chinatown are included. The local news also features an anti-eviction movement in Chinatown. Interviews with organizers from Asian Americans For Equality and building management personnel are included. Highlights from Shanghai Peking Opera troupe's performance in New York City are also showcased.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes news reports that extensively cover international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. Local news features a unionization movement organized by Chinese restaurant workers in midtown New York City. Local news also includes an award presentation ceremony organized by International Ladies Garment Workers Union (ILGWU) which presents scholarships to children of Chinese American union members. At last, a martial art contest is featured.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes news reports that cover international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The local news includes the New York City mayoral election campaigns in Chinatown. Interviews with two candidates, Frank Barbaro and Ed Koch, are included. This episode also includes interviews with Chinese Americans who will run for district representatives as Democrats. The last section of the episode includes street interviews with people about their views on roller skating.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes news reports that cover international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In local news features, the Labor Day parade in New York City, which celebrates the hundred-year anniversary of the establishment of labor unionization is highlighted. The episode also features the opening ceremony of the Products Exhibition of Jiangsu Province organized at Sino-American Commodities Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes news reports that cover international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In local news, the Labor Day parade in New York City celebrating the hundred-year anniversary of the establishment of labor unionization is covered. For the first time, Chinese American labor unions join the parade. Interviews with union leaders and members are included. News about the Peng Teng Restaurant labor strike is covered. The episode also features the opening ceremony of the Products Exhibition of Jiangsu Province organized at Sino-American Commodities Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: news reports and a current affairs forum. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The local news includes an interview with a Chinatown tenant who suffers from shortage of hot water and heating. Highlights from the Asian American Festival are also included. The second part is a current affairs forum called Fact? Debate? (事實?雄辯?). In this episode, a campaign opposes the Special Manhattan Bridge District project. The project intends to renew the neighborhood by demolishing old buildings. The representative from Community Board No. 3 (Manhattan), Virginia M. Kee, and the representative from Asian Americans For Equality, Doris Koo, express their opinions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: news reports and a social service program. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The local news features a campaign that opposes the Special Manhattan Bridge District project. The project intends to renew the neighborhood by demolishing old buildings. Chinatown residents and Asian Americans For Equality demand a public hearing in the Chinatown community. The episode also includes a feature report introducing the history of services provided by the New York Public Library Chinatown branch located at 33 East Broadway, New York City. The second part is a program called At Your Service (爲你服務) in which the Chinatown Daycare Center is featured. The Chinatown Daycare Center, founded in 1969, faces financial burden and will be demolished by the state government.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, a travel program, and a Chinese puppet show. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. A history of early Chinese immigrants in the United States is featured. The second part is a program called Travelogue (遊蹤處處) in which Orchard Crest farm in New Jersey is introduced. The third part features Chinese traditional puppet shows performed by the Quanzhou puppet troupe which originated in Fujian Province, People's Republic of China.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, a dance show, and a travel program. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. Local news includes coverage of a campaign that opposes the Special Manhattan Bridge District rezoning project. The project intends to renew the neighborhood by demolishing old buildings. Interviews with Chinatown residents being evicted are included. The episode also introduces the first generation Chinese typing computer. The second part shows performance highlights from the Chinese Dance Company of N.Y. Performances include Chinese folk dance, classic dance and martial art dance. The third part is a program called Travelogue (遊蹤處處), which covers Sheepshead Bay in New York City, New York state.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: news reports and a cultural show. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. Local news includes coverage of a campaign that opposes the Special Manhattan Bridge District rezoning project. The project intends to renew the neighborhood by demolishing old buildings. Also included in this episode is a segment on a public hearing held by Community Board No. 3 (Manhattan) to discuss the Special Manhattan Bridge District with Chinatown residents. Opinions by politicians, Chinatown residents and activists are expressed. The second part shows performances from the Chinatown Summer Cultural Festival.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, a feature on a choir, and the arrival of a Chinese opera troupe. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In local news, debts carried by the Chinatown Daycare Center are taken over by the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association. The second part features performances by a Chinese choir in New York City. The third part features Shanghai Peking Opera troupe's visit to New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, a feature report on a university information event, and a social service program. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In local news, a Chinatown physician and nurse are interviewed on how to cope with disease in the winter season; the shortage of healthcare among Chinese community is mentioned. The second part features a university information session called College Day organized by the East Coast Asian Student Union. Student representatives from different universities are interviewed. The third part is Hello Mother (哈囉阿嬸), in which the hosts interview Ms. Kwan about cosmetic and makeup skills. After the interview, Ms. Kwan holds a makeup demonstration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, an interview with a Chinese artist, and an interview with a martial arts master. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In local news, a new drama is presented by the Pan Asian Repertory. The second part features an interview with Chinese sculptor Situ Jie (司徒傑). The third part includes an interview with a martial arts master and his students. A demonstration of Chinese traditional lion dancing performance is also included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This video includes four parts: news reports, a feature on a Chinese painter, a television drama, and an interview. First, the news bulletin includes extensive coverage of international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In local news, the testimony Japanese Americans recounting being forcibly removed from their homes and mistreated by the U.S. government during World War II. The local news also includes the graduation dinner of CCTV's sixth session of the Production and Performance Workshop. The second part is a feature on Chinese painter Zhu Shengguang (朱晟光). The third part is a television drama production called Nightmare, a collective production by students from CCTV's Production and Performance workshop. The fourth part features a martial arts master who specializes in Wing Chun.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, a travel program, and a social service program. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The second part is a program called Travelogue (遊蹤處處) that highlights Walt Disney World theme park in Orlando, Florida, United States. The third part is a social service program called Portrait (特寫) which in this episode discusses neurasthenia. Street interviews with Chinatown residents and an interview with a Chinese physician about neurasthenia are included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: news reports and highlights of a cultural program. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In local news, a protest is organized by Asian Americans For Equality. The protest demands that the city redesign the Special Manhattan Bridge District rezoning project to benefit small business owners and local residents. The project intends to renew the neighborhood by demolishing old buildings. The local news also includes interviews with Chinese teenage athletes who visit New York City to attend a competition organized by the United States Association of Independent Gymnastics Club (USAIGC). The second part features a performance by a Chinese choir in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: news reports, and a travel program. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The local news includes a report on the success of the New York City janitors' strike whose demands for an increase of salary and insurance subsidy were met. The local news also includes an interview with Hong Kong singer Roman Tam (羅文) who performs in Atlantic City, New Jersey. The second part is a program called Travelogue (遊蹤處處) and covers the Walt Disney World theme park in Orlando, Florida, United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: news reports, and a cultural program. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The local news includes coverage of Christmas activities in New York City and a celebration of Christmas in Chinatown. Also included are highlights of an orchestra performance. The second part features a performance by Hong Kong singer Roman Tam (羅文) who holds solo concerts in Atlantic City, New Jersey.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: news reports, and a television drama show. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The beginning of the episode highlights the annual count-down to the New Year in Times Square, New York City. The local news covers the opposition to the Special Manhattan Bridge District rezoning project organized by Asian American for Equality. The project intends to renew the neighborhood by demolishing old buildings. The second part of the episode shows a CCTV television drama production Dream of Gold Mountain (金山夢).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, street interviews, and a feature program about Chinatown talents. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In local news, Chinatown residents and non-government organizations sue the New York City Mayor's Office of Management and Budget, New York Department of Housing and Urban Development, and a Chinese American developer on the issue of launching the Special Manhattan Bridge District project without sufficient public consultation. The project intends to renew the neighborhood by demolishing old buildings. This section also covers news about the Chinese American Planning Council, which obtained federal funds to build apartment buildings for seniors and people with disabilities. The second part includes street interviews with Chinatown residents on the topic of coping with cold weather. The third part is a feature on the first woman taxi driver from Chinatown.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, and two cultural programs. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The local news includes street interviews with Chinatown residents about the extremely cold weather they are enduring. Also in local news, a community forum is organized by a group that opposes the Special Manhattan Bridge District project. The project intends to renew the neighborhood by demolishing older buildings. The second part is a feature report on a martial arts school in Chinatown. The third part highlights Hong Kong photographer Anita Au who discusses her photographs that document 1980s city life in the People's Republic of China.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: news reports and a cultural program. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The local news includes an extensive interview with Counselor Joyce Moy who represents Chinatown residents and other non-governmental organizations in a legal pursuit against the New York City Mayor's Office of Management and Budget, the New York Department of Housing and Urban Development, and a Chinese American developer on the issue of Special Manhattan Bridge District rezoning project. The project intends to renew the neighborhood by demolishing older buildings. The local news also covers a forum organized by the Asian Americans for Equality on the issue of rental increase in Chinatown. The second part features traditional Chinese cultural activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: news reports and a cultural program. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The local news features Chinatown residents celebrating Lunar New Year, the Year of the Dog in the Chinese zodiac calendar. The news also features an Asian American literature club gathering at the Bayard Street Cafe. The second part features a performance by Hong Kong singer Alan Tam (譚詠麟) who holds solo concerts in Atlantic City, New Jersey. Tam and his girlfriend are interviewed by the host.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: news reports and a cultural program. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The local news includes an eviction case in Chinatown. The landlord of the building at 109 Madison Street Manhattan is Thomas Sun (孫啟誠). Also covered, the launch of a new Chinese newspaper called Chung Pao (中報), which is managed by Fu Chaoshu (傅朝書). The second part features a performance by Hong Kong singer Alan Tam (譚詠麟) who holds solo concerts in Atlantic City, New Jersey. Tam and his girlfriend are interviewed by the host.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, a program about Chinatown talents, and a cultural program. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The news covers an anti-eviction campaign by Manhattan Lower East Side residents; a public hearing forum is held at La Salle Academy. The second part features two Chinese American accountants who use computers to assist taxpayers with filing tax returns. The third part features the Four Seas Players' drama play 72 Tenants (七十二家房客) which is staged at Pace University in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: news reports and a television drama clip. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In local news, conflicts arise between Chinatown residents at 109 Madison Street and the landlord Thomas Sun (孫啟誠). Also included in this episode is the 1982 Harbor Festival - Salute to Asia which is held by the Port Authority at Silver Palace Restaurant in Chinatown. The local news also features an interview with Hong Kong artists Lydia Shum (沈殿霞) and Adam Cheng (鄭少秋) who hold singing concerts in Atlantic City, New Jersey. The second part shows a CCTV produced television drama production Dream of Gold Mountain (金山夢).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: a news report and a cultural program. The news report features the tenth anniversary of the signing of Three Joint Communiqués signed by the People's Republic of China and the United States. In local news, Chinese gymnastic athletes visit New York City. The second part of the episode features a concert by Hong Kong singers Lydia Shum (沈殿霞) and Adam Cheng (鄭少秋) in Atlantic City, New Jersey. Highlights of the performance and interviews with two artists are included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, a cultural program, and a review session of CCTV productions. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. Local news includes coverage of a kidnapping of a girl from Chinatown. The second part features rehearsals of Chinese classic and folk dance performances by a Chinatown dance group - New York Chinese Cultural Center. The third part compiles some popular news stories produced by CCTV, particularly anti-eviction movements responding to the Special Manhattan Bridge District rezoning project, regarded as a gentrification effort.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: news reports and a documentary. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In local news, the New York Police Department holds an educational program in Chinatown. Also covered are highlights from the English-language play The Dance and the Railroad penned by David Henry Hwang and directed by and starring John Lone. The play depicts stories of early Chinese immigrants in the United States. The final report is about an exhibition of early Chinese immigrant history organized by the New York Chinatown History Project. The second part of the episode shows clips from the documentary The Forgotten Pioneers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: news reports, studio interviews, and a preview of CCTV's new programming arrangement. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In local news, Chinatown residents participate in an anti-eviction protest. The second part includes interviews with CCTV production crew members. The third part introduces Hong Kong-origin television drama The Shell Game (千王之王) which will be shown in CCTV in April, 1982.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, street interviews, and a television drama. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In local news, the host reports on an anti-eviction protest organized by Asian Americans for Equality that led to attacks by members of a martial arts school in Chinatown. Local news also includes clips from English-language play Paper Angel which is directed by Asian American John Lone. An interview with John Lone is included. The second part includes street interviews with Chinatown residents about their views on street vendor regulations. The third part of the episode shows an episode from a 1980 Hong Kong-origin television drama The Shell Game (千王之王) .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, an interview with a talented Chinatown resident, and a television drama. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The second part features an interview with a Chinese American video technology professional who demonstrates how to clean videotape cassette players. The third part is an episode from a 1980 Hong Kong television drama The Shell Game (千王之王) .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, street interviews and a cultural program. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. Local news includes coverage of New York City mayor Ed Koch's plans to reshape Times Square and recruit more ethnic minority citizens to become civil servants. The second part includes street interviews with Chinatown residents about their views on leisure facilities in Chinatown. The third part is called Variety Show (姿彩繽紛) and shows highlights of Chinatown Summer Cultural Festival. Variety shows include Chinese classic dance, Chinese folk dance, martial art demonstration, Japanese Taiko drum performance, and Hawai'i hula dance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, an interview, and a television drama. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The local news reports on the launch of an English-Spanish-Chinese trilingual dictionary published by A.R.T.S. Inc. The second part includes an interview with a senior Chinese American who is a long-time school principal. The third part shows an episode from a 1980 Hong Kong television drama The Shell Game (千王之王) .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, interviews, and a television drama. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The local news highlights an English-language play titled J Station, which depicts the history of American concentration camps where Japanese Americans were incarcerated during World War II. The second part includes interviews with two Chinese restaurant workers who are engaged in a labor dispute with their employer. The third part is an episode from a 1980 Hong Kong television drama The Shell Game (千王之王) .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, street interviews, and a television drama. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The local news includes interviews with members of the People's Republic of China women's volleyball team who attend a tournament in New Jersey. The second part includes street interviews with Chinatown residents about their views on rising apartment rents in the neighborhood. The third part of the episode shows an episode from a 1980 Hong Kong television drama The Shell Game (千王之王) .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes two parts: news reports and a television drama. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The local news highlights a volleyball tournament between women's volleyball teams from the People's Republic of China and the United States. Interviews with the Chinese volleyball players and the team's coach are included. The second part is an episode from a 1980 Hong Kong television drama The Shell Game (千王之王) .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, a variety show, and a documentary. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news over the week. The second part is a program called Variety Show (姿彩繽紛) in which a Chinatown dance group New York Chinese Cultural Center is featured. This amateur art group practices Chinese classic dance. The third part is a Chinese documentary Ten Thousand Li Yangtze River (万里长江).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, clips from a volleyball tournament, and a television drama. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The second part shows highlights from the women's volleyball tournament between the People's Republic of China and the United States. The tournament is held at Rutgers University in New Jersey. The third part is an episode from a 1980 Hong Kong television drama The Shell Game (千王之王) .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, an interview, and a television drama. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The second part is a studio interview with the Chinese American Planning Council director about a controversial immigration reformation bill. The third part of the episode shows an episode from a 1980 Hong Kong television drama The Shell Game (千王之王) .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, street interviews, and a television drama. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In local news, conflicts arise between employers of a Chinese restaurant and their employees. The second part is street interviews with Chinatown residents about their views on cable television and CCTV programs. The third part is an episode from a 1980 Hong Kong television drama The Shell Game (千王之王) .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, an interview, and a television drama. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In local news, a career fair for ethnic minorities and women is organized by the New York City Department of Personnel. The second part includes an interview with a Chinatown couple who run a street food stall. The third part is an episode from a 1980 Hong Kong television drama The Shell Game (千王之王) .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, a cultural program, and a Chinese documentary. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news over the week. The second part introduces cultural activities about the history of early Chinese immigrants in the United States. The third part shows Chinese documentary Ten Thousand Li Yangtze River (万里长江).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, a travel program, and a television drama. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In local news, a Chinatown eviction case at 87 Madison Street is featured. The campaign is related to the launch of the Special Manhattan Bridge District rezoning project. The project is regarded as a community gentrification plan. A report shows the landlord of 87 Madison Street failing to perform proper building management and attemping to evict the tenants; affected tenants are interviewed. The second part is a program called Travelogue (遊蹤處處) where the Belmont Flea Market in New York State is introduced. The third part is an episode from a 1980 Hong Kong television drama The Shell Game (千王之王) .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, coverage of a public forum, and a television drama. The first part is news reports that covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The local news segment shows the Chinese American communities and organizations supporting the election of Chinese committee members for the New York City No. 2 geographic district community education council by-election. The second part covers a public forum held in Chinatown by the New York Hong Kong Student Association to discuss the Special Manhattan Bridge District rezoning project. The project is regarded as a community gentrification plan. The third part is an episode from a 1980 Hong Kong television drama The Shell Game (千王之王) .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, a cultural program, and a television drama. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news over the week. The local news segment covers the opposition of community organizations in Chinatown and Little Italy to building a correctional facility in the neighborhood. The second part features Chinese American fashion designer Yen Cheung. The third part of the episode shows an episode from a 1980 Hong Kong television drama The Shell Game (千王之王) .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, a cultural program, and current affairs forum. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. Local news includes a recent nation-wide mass illegal immigrant labor search action conducted by the United States immigration office. Information for Chinese American in terms of how to cope with immigration officers and how to protect citizens' legal rights is introduced by the host. The second part introduces a painting exhibition held at St. John University. The third part is a current affair forum called Fact? Debate? (事實?雄辯?). In this episode representatives from New York City Local 6 union and a Chinese restaurant labor union join the discussion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, a cultural program, and a television drama. The news reports cover international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. The second part is a program in which the host narrates the history of Chinese immigrants in the United States. The third part of the episode shows an episode from a 1980 Hong Kong television drama The Shell Game (千王之王) .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This episode includes three parts: news reports, an interview, and a television drama. The first part covers international, local, and Chinatown news from the week. In local news, New York City mayor Ed Koch supports the construction of a correctional facility in Chinatown, despite strong opposition from the residents. A Chinese American legal aid organization that serves Chinese immigrants and disadvantaged populations is also covered. The second part is an interview with Ms. Ng Po-ling (伍寶玲), a Chinese American candidate of the New York City No. 2 geographic district community education council by-election. The third part of the episode shows an episode from a 1980 Hong Kong television drama The Shell Game (千王之王) .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This video documents two Cantonese-language musical performances. The first covers a photo exhibition by Chinese Americans of anti-Japan campaigns; the exhibition is accompanied by Cantonese folk songs. A clip of a Chinese old man's Cantonese folk song singing performance is included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This video includes an interview with Chinese American artists who participate in an exhibition at Washington Square Park, New York City, a chewing gum advertisement produced by the second session of CCTV Production and Performance workshop, a sit-com featuring miscommunication between Mandarin and Cantonese speaking families, and interviews with Confucius Plaza residents. Also included is an interview with Mr. Lo, the vice-chairman of Confucius Plaza co-op project. He introduces the history of building the Confucius Plaza which is under the Mitchell-Lama Housing Program. The episode also shows a situation drama which features dilemmas in a Chinese American family. The end of the episode includes clips of lectures during the second CCTV Production and Performance workshop.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Asian CineVision (ACV) is a non-profit media arts organization that develops, promotes and preserves media made by or about peoples of Asian descent. Asian CineVision was founded by grassroots media activists in New York's Chinatown in 1976 to raise social and cultural awareness of the Asian American experience, both in the Asian American community and among the general public. CineVue Online is ACV's media arts journal established in 1986. The websites contains their media arts journal, information on their Asian American International Film Festival, specifically the 2014-2018 editions of the festival, news listings, event listings, trailers and descriptions of films in the festival, and press releases.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: http://www.asiancinevision.org/ is accrued semiannually. https://www.aaiff.org/ is accrued quarterly.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Due to technical or privacy issues, archived websites may not be exact copies of the original website at the time of the web crawl. Certain file types will not be captured dependent on how they are embedded in the site. Other parts of websites that the crawler has difficulty capturing includes Javascript, streaming content, database-driven content, and highly interactive content. Full-Text searches of archived websites are available at https://archive-it.org/organizations/567.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: Crawl was limited to domains and subdomains of aaiff.org and asiancinevision.org in order to remain within the collection scope and data constraints.
